sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• piperaquine/dihydroartemisinin has centralized marketing authorization by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) for use in the European Union (EU)
  • Falciparum malaria: (24 to less than 36 kg) piperaquine 640 mg/dihydroartemisinin 80 mg ORALLY once daily for 3 days; MAX not to exceed 3 courses in 12 months; if needed, start second course at least 2 months after completing first course (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)
  • Falciparum malaria: (36 to less than 75 kg) piperaquine 960 mg/dihydroartemisinin 120 mg ORALLY once daily for 3 days; MAX not to exceed 3 courses in 12 months; if needed, start second course at least 2 months after completing first course (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)
  • Falciparum malaria: (75 to less than 100 kg) piperaquine 1280 mg/dihydroartemisinin 160 mg ORALLY once daily for 3 days; MAX not to exceed 3 courses in 12 months; if needed, start second course at least 2 months after completing first course (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• piperaquine/dihydroartemisinin has centralized marketing authorization by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) for use in the European Union (EU)
  • safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients younger than 6 months or in pediatric patients weighing less than 5 kg
  • Falciparum malaria: (5 to less than 7 kg) piperaquine 80 mg/dihydroartemisinin 10 mg ORALLY once daily for 3 days; MAX not to exceed 3 courses in 12 months; if needed, start second course at least 2 months after completing first course (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)
  • Falciparum malaria: (7 to less than 13 kg) piperaquine 160 mg/dihydroartemisinin 20 mg ORALLY once daily for 3 days; MAX not to exceed 3 courses in 12 months; if needed, start second course at least 2 months after completing first course (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)
  • Falciparum malaria: (13 to less than 24 kg) piperaquine 320 mg/dihydroartemisinin 40 mg ORALLY once daily for 3 days (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing); MAX not to exceed 3 courses in 12 months; if needed, start second course at least 2 months after completing first course
  • Falciparum malaria: (24 to less than 36 kg) piperaquine 640 mg/dihydroartemisinin 80 mg ORALLY once daily for 3 days; MAX not to exceed 3 courses in 12 months; if needed, start second course at least 2 months after completing first course (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)
  • Falciparum malaria: (36 to less than 75 kg) piperaquine 960 mg/dihydroartemisinin 120 mg ORALLY once daily for 3 days; MAX not to exceed 3 courses in 12 months; if needed, start second course at least 2 months after completing first course (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)
  • Falciparum malaria: (75 to less than 100 kg) piperaquine 1280 mg/dihydroartemisinin 160 mg ORALLY once daily for 3 days; MAX not to exceed 3 courses in 12 months; if needed, start second course at least 2 months after completing first course (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: vomiting: if vomiting occurs within 30 minutes of administration, then re-administer dose; if vomiting occurs between 30 to 60 minutes of administration, then re-administer one-half the dose; if vomiting occurs after second dose, then find alternative therapy; do not re-administer more than once

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• arrhythmias, symptomatic, or with clinically relevant bradycardia
  • cardiac conditions predisposing for arrhythmia, including severe hypertension, left ventricular hypertrophy (including hypertrophic cardiomyopathy), or congestive cardiac failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction
  • concomitant use or recent use (if still in system circulation) with QT-prolonging agents
  • electrolyte disturbances, especially hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, or hypomagnesemia
  • hypersensitivity to piperaquine, dihydroartemisinin, or any component of the product
  • malaria, severe (WHO definition)
  • QT prolongation, congenital, or sudden death, family history
  • QT prolongation, congenital, or any condition known to prolong the QT interval

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• breastfeeding during therapy; not recommended
  • concomitant use with grapefruit juice should be avoided
  • concomitant use with rifampicin, carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, St John's Wort (hypericum perforatum); not recommended
  • falciparum malaria, severe; use not recommended
  • hepatic impairment, moderate to severe, with/without jaundice; monitoring recommended
  • pregnancy; use not recommended unless no other suitable agents available
  • QT prolongation has occurred; increased risk in female patients, elderly patients, young children who are vomiting, and those receiving CYP3A4 substrates or inhibitors; monitoring recommended, particularly in patients with increased risk of developing arrhythmia
  • renal impairment, moderate to severe; monitoring recommended

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Prolonged QT interval (adults, 1% to less than 10%; pediatrics, 1% to less than 10%)
  • Immunologic:Falciparum malaria (adults, 1% to less than 10%; pediatrics, 3% or greater), Influenza (pediatrics, 10% or greater)
  • Respiratory:Cough (adults, 0.1% to less than 1%; pediatrics, 10% or greater)
  • Other:Fever (adults, 1% to less than 10%; pediatrics, 1.5% or greater)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Abnormal cardiac conduction (0.1% to less than 1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Necrotizing enterocolitis in fetus OR newborn, Leukocytoses (pediatrics, 1% to less than 10%)
  • Hematologic:Leukocytosis, Necrotizing enterocolitis (pediatrics, 1% to less than 10%), Neutropenia (pediatrics, 1% to less than 10%), Thrombocytopenia (pediatrics, 1% to less than 10%)
  • Hepatic:Hepatitis (0.1% to less than 1%)
  • Neurologic:Seizure (0.1% to less than 1%)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • take with water only and without food; take no less than 3 hours after any food intake; do not eat for 3 hours after taking each dose
  • tablets may be crushed, mixed with water, and given immediately for patients unable to swallow tablets
